Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Computer Vision

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This project represents a continuation of a Research Experience for Undergraduates site in Computer Vision which has operated successfully at the University of Central Florida for the past twenty four years. Approximately two hundred and forty undergraduate students from forty-five institutions all over the country have participated in this program over the years. The research focus area is Computer Vision. The current proposal is to have 10 participants per year, for three years. Each year, students will participate in a 12-week duration full-time Summer program. From lessons learned in prior years, the proposed model includes round-the-clock mentoring by a team that includes a professor, and a post-doctoral fellow or a graduate student; a streamlined short course that lets participants start their research projects sooner; daily meetings with mentors to plan activities throughout the day; training in MatLab for quick turnaround of research ideas. Participants take the short course, match themselves to a project topic that they most desire, and spend sufficient time in focused research. They then can opt for follow-through over the year by working with the professors to write a technical report on their project, to prepare for the GREs and to apply to graduate programs. In past years, a substantial fraction of our REU participants have been able to prepare a paper for submission to a refereed conference, have the paper accepted and then attend the conference to present the paper.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thirty-one U.S. undergraduates (citizens and permanent residents) in computer science and engineering  have been trained in research procedures during a twelve-week summer immersion at UCF. Focused on the area that gives computers the power to visually see, the students were first provided training in the concepts and procedures that lead to exploration in this field. Then, the students were introduced to many on-going projects led by advanced researchers and were encouraged to choose and commit to one project. In subsequent weeks, under the guidance of the advanced researchers, the students worked to put into practice their recently learned skills with the aim  of discovering or inventing previously unknown technological capabilities.

All students completed a project report, and seven students completed reports that won placement in highly competitive, reviewed, scientific publication venues. In addition to strengthening their abilities to conduct research, all students were taken on field trips to interact with Corporate personnel who conduct similar research, and were provided with substantial information on how to continue their pathway as a researcher by enrolling in competitive training programs (graduate study) .

 

Intellectual Merits:

All students were involved in investigating and pursuing the creation of new knowledge. A new capability for tracking the movements within large crowds was created. A new capability to analyze visual resemblance in parent-child pairings was created. New capabilities for using geographic information systems to assist with visual recognition of objects and structures in scenes, were invented. A method was developed to analyze the visual content of selfie images that enables their popularity to be dissected.

 

Broader Impacts:

The training model has achieved a high degree of success in providing undergraduates with good preparation to become advanced researchers. The model is very suitable for successfully training a diverse population of students.
